events.target_title: Cannot print to IPP printers from the GTK dialog
Cannot print to IPP printers from the GTK dialog

note.body:
As I understand it, DNS-SD broadcasts of remote CUPR servers are browsed and their queues displayed in the dialog. That happens with or without the cups service being operative on the client. On this machine it is stopped. I have no problem printing to any of the enumerated queues, so there is no issue there.

The DNS-SD broadcasts of IPP printers (common on recent printers) are also browsed and the dialog shows a not very useful "print" as the destination and the the message "Rejecting Jobs". Again, this is irrespective of the cups service being operative on the client. There is no support from  cupsd (libcups2 is all that is needed) and I cannot think of anything to debug.

If CUPS servers are supported by the dialog but not IPP printers, it would be nice to know.

-- 
Brian.

events.target_title: Cannot print to IPP printers from the GTK dialog

note.body:
With the help of ngrep I can now advance what I think is a reasonable answer to the implied question in the final paragraph of my previous post.

GTK uses the rp= key (not the pdl= key as I thought initially) of DNS-SD broadcasts to get the queue/printer destination and a PPD. For a CUPS server with advertised queues, rp is always printers/destination. That gives a destination to display in the dialog and the means to obtain printers/destination.ppd via HTTP.

On the other hand, the resource path for an IPP URI has never been formally standardised but nowadays rp is likely to be ipp/print. This leads to the possibility that many IPP printers on the same subnet have a destination of "print". But no two printers or queues are allowed the same name. That accounts for one of my observations. (With another printer having rp=ipp/printer, two IPP printers would find a place in the dialog).

Getting a PPD with HTTP and ipp/print is also going to be problematic. This accounts for "Getting printer information..." indefinitely in response to selecting the "print" entry.

I think I know where I am up to now, but I suppose the question has changed to "will the GTK dialog ever support IPP printers?"

-- 
Brian.

events.target_title: Print dialog box shows unwanted printers

note.body:
>  ls: cannot access '/etc/cups/ppp': No such file or directory

A typo. "ppp" should be "ppd".

>  How to stop cups-browser? ps aux|grep cups does not show it.

Either cups-browsed is not running or it is not on the system.

A better command to determine which it is, is:

`systemctl status cups-browsed`

>  What should I do to have the dialog box show only the 4 printers in CUPS and get rid of the 5th entry?

You cannot. The dialog does not have the means to filter out the HP Deskjet 3070 B611 series it has discovered on the network.

You could turn off Bonjour on the printer to not see it.

events.target_title: Cannot print to IPP printers from the GTK dialog

note.body:
I understand the intention of commit 68bf781e (if not the code) and it is a step forward. Thanks.

However, many IPP printers accept only MIME type image/urf. For a printer to be given that, it has to be processed by cups-filters on Debian and, AFAICT, that cannot be done without cups-browsed on the system. The cups-browsed queue entry is, of course, not the same entry we are discussing.

Regards,

Brian.

events.target_title: Print dialog box shows unwanted printers

note.body:
>  (Note that since the submission of this bug, I removed one of the printers, hence I have only three printers in cups.)

A PPD in /etc/cups/ppd indicates a local queue. I wanted to confirm that you did not have cups-browsed running. You do not and don't need it for your setup.

>  That printer is not on my machine, it is on someone else's machine, so I cannot turn off Bonjour on it... And perhaps he needs it for another machine.

I had a suspicion the printer was not under your control. Nothing you can do at that end then.

The issue is one for the GTK dialog, not CUPS or cups-browsed. You have put your report in the right place

Regards,

Brian.

events.target_title: Print dialogue has a printer called "printer"

note.body:
>  And that "printer" isn't a printer that I added, and is always shown as "rejecting jobs".

The ML-2950 shown in the dialog is not a printer but a print queue which has either been set up with the CUPS web interface, lpadmin etc or automatically set up by cups-browsed. We know it is not a printer because it appears in the lpstat output and lpstat shows local queues only. There will be a PPD for it in /etc/cups/ppd.

The "print" entry is a printer on the network (the ML-2950) doing Bonjour broadcasting. The GTK dialog browses the Bonjour broadcasts directly and lists it. (But as you saw, the printer cannot be printed to).

It is easy enough to filter out or get rid of the ML-2950 queue entry. No duplicates then. But no printing either! The ML-2950 "print" entry cannot be filtered out.

-- 
Brian.

Kerberos: temporary accounts not cleaned up, spams journal at crazy high rate
Kerberos: temporary accounts not cleaned up, spams journal at crazy high rate

note.body:
> I think I have narrowed this down to the use of Kerberos' KCM caches and kinit 

I was indeed using a KCM ticket cache.

> Or, you could try not using a KCM cache by removing the sssd-kcm package that provides /etc/krb5.conf.d/kcm_default_ccache on Fedora 

This workaround seems to work - no more spamming. Thanks!
Please note that this is not a fix, though. The reason for using `sssd-kcm` was that eventually, SSSD will [hopefully](https://pagure.io/SSSD/sssd/issue/1723) support ticket renewal for all channels obtained through `sssd-kcm`, which I would like to use. Since this is not implemented yet, I'm fine with the workaround for now.


> Either use the Online Accounts panel in Settings to obtain the Kerberos ticket, instead of kinit on the command line.  

That's not really an option, we use SSSD for logins.

events.target_title: Hard to control what the Wifi is doing: No way to actively disconnect from a connection

note.body:
> It's hard to tell what to do for the other issues without having a description of how it worked in 3.24. Maybe someone else can chime in with that information.

My suggestion:

A simple "disconnect" button would help significantly. After it is pressed, automatic connection should be blocked until it is reestablished manually (by selecting a network) or by turning WiFi or airplane mode off and on again.

Potentially, automatic reconnection could also be blocked after a failed connection attempt. Windows does this for example, but that could be considered undesired behaviour and would need to be discussed more broadly.

events.target_title: Kerberos: temporary accounts not cleaned up, spams journal at crazy high rate

note.body:
@nill22.25 nope, unfortunately not.

On Fedora, my current workaround is to murder the GOA binary through RPM hooks: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1379070#c22


```
rpmdev-setuptree

cat > ~/rpmbuild/SPECS/kill-goa.spec << EOF
Name:           kill-goa
Version:        1
Release:        1%{?dist}
Summary:        Ensures that gnome-online-accounts is disabled
BuildArch: noarch

License:        BSD

%description
Ensures that gnome-online-accounts is disabled

%files

%filetriggerin -- /usr/libexec/goa-daemon
ln -sf /dev/null /usr/libexec/goa-daemon

%changelog
* Thu Aug  9 2018 Alexander Korsunsky <alexander.korsunsky@rcpe.at>
- 
EOF

rpmbuild -bb ~/rpmbuild/SPECS/kill-goa.spec
sudo rpm -i ~/rpmbuild/RPMS/noarch/kill-goa*.rpm
sudo dnf reinstall gnome-online-accounts
```

If you have another distro, you'll have to find another way to make sure that `/usr/libexec/goa-daemon` stays deleted.

note.body:
Hello, just tried to triage a [crash report](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=926212#10) in debian bugtracker. Unfortunately there I have just current instruction pointer.

However, I guess this bug appears when ```app->running_state``` is valid, but ```app->running_state->windows``` contains a null pointer.

There are some more gnome-shell bugs that point to [shell-app.c, line 1485](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/src/shell-app.c#L1485), which may be caused by this.

A [fedora bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1654420#c28) points into a similar direction, while having also ```_shell_app_remove_window``` same frames before in the stack.

note.body:
i compiled 2.45.2 and the results were the same.

However, i installed fedora 29 (virtualmachine also) and things are a bit different. F29 ships with 2.44.6 and for my surprise rsvg-view showed the figure as it should be! I compiled 2.45.2 and the results did not changed (i.e., figure was correct)

I have no idea why on manjaro (and mint) the overlap is displayed while on F29 there is no overlap.

Since librsvg needs some pre-requisites to be compiled, could it be some of those? Or maybe on F29 there is a parameter/variable/option enabled or disabled by default. I have no clues at all.

Will try to figure it out, but i have no hopes.

note.body:

Nautilus - 3.26.4

Is there fix, or at least a workaround for this?

events.target_title: nautilus 3.26.0 can't generate thumbnails

note.body:
No problem. I managed to fix it myself by installing package bubblewrap https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/bubblewrap. Looks like it's not installed with gnome-desktop but is a dependency. Also, seems the name may have changed from previously being bwrap. 

Can confirm this works. Will update the open ticket.

-- SSS

events.target_title: Can't generate thumbnails

note.body:
Installing package bubblewrap https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/bubblewrap resolved this for me. Looks like it's not installed with gnome-desktop but is a dependency. Also, seems the name may have changed from previously being bwrap.

Can confirm this works my end on pop!_os 18.04 LTS. 

Nautilus - 3.26.4
Gnome Shell - 3.28.2

-- SSS

events.target_title: Allow for the menubar to be placed in the server-side decorations (locally integrated menu)
Allow for the menubar to be placed in the server-side decorations (locally integrated menu)

note.body:
PS: I think there is so much enthusiasm among users for this that any developers who wish to work on this feature would be able to raise plenty of donations to compensate their efforts. The benefit isn't small. It allows developers to get something like native headerbars for free. And it allows users to save lots of vertical space, get a reasonably consistent environment, and access features like HUD, which is very productive for apps like LibreOffice.

Alternately, if it becomes possible to add arbitrary widgets to the decoration, this would be a step towards DWD, where apps could get real headerbars and rich HUD screens.

events.target_title: New theme seems excessively and needlessly vibrant
New theme seems excessively and needlessly vibrant

note.body:
I mean primarily the blue and the vanilla, you're right about the shadows too - not my preference. The blue is really loud imo, while the vanilla isn't neutral. 

I don't mean the new theme is horrible or that big a change, it's just look kind of annoying to me.

My main point is that there are good reasons to prefer the older style. So I am suggesting keeping it as an option. The two themes could probably me made extremely similar, with the exception of a few variables, to minimize any conceivable maintenance pain. 

Also, I thought I read something icon theme being programmable (or something). Is there a chance of color palettes being swappable as far as the icons are concerned (i.e colors get replaced). So you could go, say from the new color palette to the old one? That'd be really interesting to see.

events.target_title: New theme seems excessively and needlessly vibrant

note.body: The two themes would have a code base that's 99.9% identical and the new theme - unlike the old one - isn't neutral enough to be sole default theme. Sure someone could package the old theme, but it's not going to be available to the end user. It's going to be available via flatpak commandline and a PPA. Plus the new theme has no viable QT equivalent (yet), so users will have no way to get a consistent experience on their desktop.

events.target_title: configure fails with 'autoconf-archive missing'
configure fails with 'autoconf-archive missing'

note.body:
Hi Christoph,

Not sure what you mean. Do you mean download autoconf-archive from one of the mirrors i.e. http://mirror.its.dal.ca/gnu/autoconf-archive/? Then unpack it, ./configure, make, make install? I have done this and all it does is create this structure

| autoconf-archive

|| 2018.03.13

||| share

|||| aclocal

||||| <all the macros>.m4

|||| autoconf-archive

||||| <readme files>

|||| info

||||| <more readme>

So I have the macros under this aclocal directory. However this is separate from my autoconf path. Do I copy them into the autoconf path? If so, how?

| autoconf

|| 2.69

||| bin

|||| <executables, such as autoconf, autoheader, autoreconf, etc>

||| share

|||| autoconf

||||| autoconf

|||||| <the default macros + the ones from the archive I copied into here from aclocal from above>

||||| Autom4te

|||||| <.pm files>

I hope this directory listing is clear enough (how do I show my directory structure? This is hard to format). I can run the autoconf/2.69/bin utilities fine, I have this bin in my $PATH, but how do I make the other macros available?

No matter where I put the archive macros, I still get the error that 'autoconf-archive is missing' - how does the 'configure' script look for this archive?

Thank you for the response.

events.target_title: configure fails with 'autoconf-archive missing'

note.body:
Ah unfortunately I cannot install to /usr/.. or any of those directories, I am providing software using environment modules so I have to install to a specific central location. I have autotools in its own folder.

Based on this line

m4_ifndef([AX_COMPILER_FLAGS], [AC_MSG_ERROR(['autoconf-archive' missing])])

And I am not very familiar with this language but it's saying if AX_COMPILER_FLAGS is not defined, it throws the error? Is this variable supposed to point to the path with the macros? Can I just set it myself?

I did try ./configure with AX_COMPILER_FLAGS=/path/autoconf/2.69/share/autoconf/autoconf which is the directory that contains all of the macros from autoconf-archive (in addition to the default autoconf macros). I also tried pointing to /path/autoconf-archive/2018.03.13/share/aclocal, /path/autoconf-archive/2018.03.13/share, /path/autoconf-archive/2018.03.13, and /path/autoconf-archive.

If I can define these paths myself using environment variables that'd be my preferred way to do it.

events.target_title: configure fails with 'autoconf-archive missing'

note.body:
Hi Emmanuele,

My questions are around how this piece of software looks for these autoconf macros. There isn't a library to point to, it's a bunch of .m4 files. So I am unclear how to include the directory that contains the m4 macros as I don't know how it checks for them. What does jhbuild do that I can't just supply myself with additional variables? I'm not looking for another way of compiling software here. I mean I know it's not your issue per se but the issue arises from trying to compile your software so I'm just hoping for some explanations of how it works - not sure who else I can ask for help on this as autoconf has worked for me in many other instances and it's only with gobject-introspection that it is iffy.

Hi Christoph,

To clarify do you mean that gobject-introspection is looking for an 'aclocal' directory in ACLOCAL_PATH and this 'aclocal' directory containing the autoconf-archive macros? I did put autoconf-archive's aclocal directory into the ACLOCAL_PATH which didn't solve it.

I appreciate your help with this issue. I do have the AX_COMPILER_FLAGS macro in a few locations including the main autoconf macros directory but it's still not finding it? I don't suppose I could point to it directly somehow. I mean this macro definitely exists.

I tried copying it to /usr/share/aclocal/ax_compiler_flags.m4 but it still didn't find it.

note.body: Ah ok, thanks for the help anyway. You've sent me down a more productive path than I was before! Cheers.

events.target_title: Offline Google Drive Syncing
Offline Google Drive Syncing

note.body:
Interesting. Thanks for pointing out libcloudproviders.

Suppose such a libcloudproviders-aware client existed for Google Drive that provided this offline behavior I mentioned. Would it then make sense to use that by default when a user links their account? I guess what I'm asking is: is the current default behavior of google-drive mounts preferable, or should it be replaced with the client I'm proposing?

events.target_title: Add support for in-fs move and copy

note.body: Ondrej, would you by any chance remember the reason why applications needed to map volatile paths instead of the backend doing that transparently? Previous posts suggest this has something to do with Drive being more "racy", but I fail to see how one client's own internal mapping between POSIX-style paths (used by GIO) and Drive IDs would expose applications to any race conditions.

events.target_title: Offline Google Drive Syncing

note.body:
Still trying to decide where this would need to be implemented. If I did write a libcloudprovider client, at the moment that would only allow nautilus to access the drive files, correct? There is no mention in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/324 of libgio, so I guess unlike the case with google-drive mounts, applications would only have access to the files that were synced through nautilus. That doesn't seem like much of a drawback, as that is how the official client works on all supported platforms.

As for the design discussion, what would be the correct place for that? Should I open another issue (if so, where)?

events.target_title: Offline Google Drive Syncing

note.body: @csoriano I don't see why that's the case. I'd be inclined to agree if GNOME didn't already provide google drive integration through GVFS, but that is not the case. The current implementation is not what the typical user is after, and we should either have something usable or nothing at all. (Not to mention, I've made some headway in the client and I'm already invested :smile: ).

events.target_title: add file/folder sync support

note.body:
I've been working on this on-and-off for some time now. This is where I'm at:
1) I added support for the changes API to libgdata
2) I have an untested implementation of a libcloudproviders sync client that mimics the behavior of the Windows Backup and Sync client (with the exception that changes are polled for by the client instead of being pushed, as that would require a web service).

Before discussing the implementation, I think we need to agree on what approach makes the most sense. I'll lay out my arguments below (I understand it's all subjective):

1) While there are use cases for the current gvfs implementation, I don't think they are compelling enough for the typical user not to just open drive.google.com to manually download/upload.
2) I thought the gvfs implementation using volatile paths was well-conceived, but the challenges--and the proposed remedies using AppProperties--have made things a little convoluted.
3) Is GVfs really the correct place to have support for popular cloud storage services, or is it intended to be an abstraction layer for different transfer protocols?

I think a libcloudproviders sync client is more suited for this purpose, but I'm not yet sure where it would fit in. I'd like to share what I have so far if we decide to go this route.

events.target_title: Avatar border stretches when alongside tall message
Avatar border stretches when alongside tall message

note.body: I found a way to fix the problem: using the GTK Inspector, selecting the GtkBox holding the avatar and changing `valign` to `GTK_ALIGN_START` fixes the issue (before it was `GTK_ALIGN_FILL` which is probably self-evident as to why it was causing stretching).

events.target_title: Avatar border stretches when alongside tall message

note.body: Probably adding something like `b.set_valign(gtk::Align::Start);` (may not be exactly correct) after [this line](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/fractal/blob/master/fractal-gtk/src/widgets/avatar.rs#L67) in avatar.rs would probably fix it, though I might be wrong or this may not be the best place to put it.

events.target_title: Windows distribution & installer

note.body:
I think supporting Win XP is a waste of time (dead OS), even if I still have it on my old development machine. I just don't have a newer Windows license and switched to Linux end of 2014.

About dia-win-remote.exe and diaw.exe:
These files are used on windows for shell integration. For example the old installer has this code:

`  WriteRegStr HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT "diaFile\Shell\open\command" "" '"$INSTDIR\bin\dia-win-remote.exe" diaw.exe --integrated "%1"'`


`    WriteRegStr HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT "diaFile\Shell\createcgm\command" "" '"$INSTDIR\bin\diaw.exe" -t cgm "%1"'`

dia-win-remote.exe was somehow needed to find an already running instance. Opening a diagram with double-click adds a new tab with the diagram in an old instance instead of creating a new instance.

events.target_title: Windows distribution & installer

note.body:
I had a chance to do a very quick test on Win 10.
It works in English. :) It doesn't in German. :(

*  dia.exe [new] is like diaw.exe [old]: It opens a new Dia instance. 
*  dia.exe [old] opens Dia and an addtional console window (for messages)
*  dia-win-remote.exe [old] uses already open instance

It seems that dia.exe [new] doesn't find the translation files dia.mo. The old packages had even more translation files included.
The translation files [old] are located here (for German)
*  \locale\de\LC_MESSAGES: 
dia.mo
*  \share\locale\de\LC_MESSAGES: 
glib20.mo, gtk20-properties.mo, gtk20.mo
*  \lib\locale\de\LC_MESSAGES: 
atk10.mo

events.target_title: Investigate making thumbnailing faster

note.body: So I was investigating a slowdown in eog while auto-reloading SVG files, and it seems the problem was in the thumbnail generation, which was taking ~10s. (For a tiny SVG, mind you.) More specifically, `gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer` complained about not finding a font config and spent a lot of time looking at fonts. Adding `--ro-bind /var/cache/fontconfig /var/cache/fontconfig` to the arguments for `bwrap` fixed the issue and the time is down to ~0.2s.

events.target_title: gimp 2.10 won't open or save files referenced by symbolic links or on partitions other than root

note.body:
I tried to install 2.10.12 again from the standard software manager. It's Snap, as I see:
![1](/uploads/6eca7c591decbdddcb23316c95f8bcd5/1.png)

It still has the issues as I said before. To get rid from some of them you have to (*surprise!*) give permissions to the app:
![2](/uploads/b5d2b464e5b9ec0b8fe2e2a05880c46b/2.png)

After that, GIMP can open files from /mnt/Data/ and also folders via simlinks, but **it still can't open files from /tmp**, because (*surprise again!*) **/tmp in GIMP is not system /tmp folder**, it's some another "virtual" folder. What the hack? I use /tmp folder to keep (*surprise?*) temporary files and quite often graphical files.
![3](/uploads/b28e55dc8e1c51c67081cb5ff84fbd8b/3.png)

**If you have a petition against Snap, I would sign it!**

events.target_title: Ubuntu 18.04 Files won't remember afp password for NAS

note.body:
So poked around a bit further down the rabbit hole.

Umounting and mounting via the CLI works fine:

```
$ gio mount afp://Nigel%20Stewart@nas.local/home/
...
$ gio mount -u afp://Nigel%20Stewart@nas.local/home/
..
```

(With no prompt for user/password)

But mounting via Files prompts for user/password once gvfsd restarted via:

```
$ /usr/lib/gvfs/gvfsd -r -d &
```

events.target_title: Ubuntu 18.04 Files won't remember afp password for NAS

note.body:
> you use the volume which is automatically listed in "Other Locations" in the "Networks" sections

Yes.

> Does it work without the password .. in the "Connect to server" entry and press "Connect"? 

Yes.

> What is output from `gio list dns-sd://local/`?

```
$ gio list dns-sd://local/
dp-63520GE7._sftp-ssh._tcp
nas._webdavs._tcp
nas._webdav._tcp
nas._afpovertcp._tcp
```

![Screenshot_from_2018-12-17_23-40-02](/uploads/b32fe3b07b082027d86d9f0b726c12ad/Screenshot_from_2018-12-17_23-40-02.png)

events.target_title: Ubuntu 18.04 Files won't remember afp password for NAS

note.body:
```
$ gio list -a "standard::target-uri" dns-sd://local/
dp-63520GE7._sftp-ssh._tcp	0	(shortcut)	standard::target-uri=sftp://dp-63520GE7.local:22/
nas._webdavs._tcp	0	(shortcut)	standard::target-uri=davs+sd://nas._webdavs._tcp.local
nas._webdav._tcp	0	(shortcut)	standard::target-uri=dav+sd://nas._webdav._tcp.local
nas._afpovertcp._tcp	0	(shortcut)	standard::target-uri=afp://nas.local:548/
```

One aspect that got my attention is that on `nas.local` the WebDav ports are non-standard.

The zeroconf is missing the `u` TXT (for username, I think), but also I'm not sure the port information is being picked up.

```
$ avahi-browse -a -r
...
= enp6s0 IPv4 nas                                           WebDAV File Share    local
   hostname = [nas.local]
   address = [10.0.0.22]
   port = [5005]
   txt = []
...
= enp6s0 IPv4 nas                                           Secure WebDAV File Share local
   hostname = [nas.local]
   address = [10.0.0.22]
   port = [5006]
   txt = []
```

This does work: `davs://Nigel%20Stewart@nas.local:5006/home`

note.body:
Hi, @egmontkob 

Thank you for your explaination, didn't realize it's causing so many breaks :sob: After that, I also noticed that my favorite triple-click-to-select-line function is broken too, so I re-thought about it, and came up with a new solution.

We can deselect the selection only on button releases and button motions if the motions are about to select content. I tested that and it seems no break is introduced.

Patch is here, please review it for me, thanks :)

[0001-widget-optimize-selection-maintaining-on-button-even.patch](/uploads/6b7c2e53ba96c3cd698c4c8d073d0726/0001-widget-optimize-selection-maintaining-on-button-even.patch)

events.target_title: Long press on selections cause deselection

note.body:
> This patch doesn't compile.

Whoops... very sorry for that, deepin-terminal vendored the latest vte code, so I did the change there, tested the function, looked good and did the change to my vte repository, seems I was high and forgot to test the patch before sending it here :stuck\_out\_tongue\_winking\_eye:  Anyway I attached a fixed one.

> If I understand correctly, you're about to deselect on mouse release all the time, even when clicked outside of the selection. It's not necessarily bad, but differs from the current experience and the experience provided by other apps that deselecting occurs on click (if outside the selection).

Yes, but if you want I think I can add some code to hold the `pressing outside the select to deselect` behavior. 

> In fact, this behavior might be more aligned with the reason the move threshold was introduced. It was introduced not to lose selection in other apps on a click (and perhaps an unintentional tiny movement), but I'm wondering if it should also apply to the case when the old selection is also within this VTE...

sorry, I don't really understand `It was introduced not to lose selection in other apps on a click`.

> So, what will happen in Deepin Terminal on a long click? The click is forwarded from Deepin Terminal to VTE, D-T then knows by the timing that it's a long click, presents its own menu or whatever, and it never sends a release event? 

The session daemon of DDE sends right clicks when it recognized that the user tapped and hold for a little while on the touchscreen, Deepin Terminal, likes all other normal terminal emulators, will show the context menu on receiving right clicks.

> Then VTE believes the mouse is still pressed, and will start a selection when you move it? Or what exactly?

Actually, I don't know, I think vte won't receive the release event, but I tested that it seems that not receiving the release event didn't cause any problem, please help me to check on that.


> > long-press-right-click
> To clarify: we're not talking about long-press of the right button, we're talking about long-press of the normal button (or the touch screen) which is expected to behave as a right-click, correct?

Correct.

> Isn't / shouldn't this be handled on a lower level, e.g. X/Wayland driver, Deepin desktop, or GTK+? Edit: or probably straight in the hardware, just like presumably on my laptop's touchpad?

libinput leaves that to the GUI toolkit, but press events are always sent before a gesture event, vte just deselect the selection, so it's too late to when the gesture events come.

[0001-widget-optimize-selection-maintaining-on-button-even.patch](/uploads/6c4da579a4c7b8684fe7380f2257110d/0001-widget-optimize-selection-maintaining-on-button-even.patch)

Thank you @chpe for pointing out the vendoring problem, I'm not maintainer of deepin-terminal until recently, and I'm not very like vendoring vte in deepin-terminal, so I'll probably remove it in the near future.

events.target_title: Long press on selections cause deselection

note.body:
> I've tried deepin-terminal (on Ubuntu 18.10, Unity 7 desktop – not the entire Deepin desktop experience).

> The right-click and hamburger menus can be opened multiple times at once. This is extremely unusual, pointless and confusing to me.

> The latest one grabs the keyboard, but not the mouse, I can focus other apps and use the mouse in them but cannot type into them. I'm getting even more confused. I can close the latest menu by hitting Escape.

> Once I close it, the remaining (previously opened) menus don't grab the keyboard. There's no intuitive way to close those menus at all. The mouse isn't grabbed, it operates on the window underneath. The keyboard isn't grabbed, an Escape or any other keypress is sent to the focused window. I found two ways of closing the menu: by invoking one of its entries (and seeing that action getting executed); or by clicking on one of the thin separator lines between its entries, or the very top or very bottom, in order to dismiss it without side effect. Yet even more confusing and user-unfriendly.

> And I haven't even mentioned that these menus can outlive the window they were opened for, and even the entire application that opened them. (Apparently there's a separate deepin-menu process responsible for them – killing that process is a third way of closing the menus.) I really don't know what to expect from invoking the context menu of a no longer available context, let alone a no longer running process.

> This all might easily be irrelevant to the current topic, but at least makes me more skeptical whether Deepin is heading in the right direction.

That's because the context menu of deepin-terminal is provided by a separate process, we do that because we use Qt and GTK in our DE development, and intend to provde a menu service, so both tool kits will show same style menus.

there're issues here and there in packages on ubuntu, because they're not being maintaned for a long time.

events.target_title: Long press on selections cause deselection

note.body:
So back to the topic, the main problem somes like this: 

1. user selected something.
2. user tapped on the selection. deepin-terminal recoganized that as left button press and forwarded it to vte.
3. vte deselect the selection.
4. after a period of time, dde-session-daemon recognized the tap-and-hold gesture, sent a right button press event.
5. deepin-terminal received the event and show the context menu (but the selection is already disappeared).
6. dde-session-daemon sent a right button release event...

With my patch, vte don't deselect on pressing, but on releasing and dragging. And I don't know how, but the corresponding release event of step 2 is recevied by vte after the user release the tap.

Hope I have made myself clear this time.

events.target_title: Long press on selections cause deselection

Yeah, I totally understand that :) and I'm not trying to get my patch merged, I just want to provide as much information as I can (including patches) so that you can help me solve my issue quicklier since I believe you guys got better knowledge on GTK/VTE than me.

> Does it mean that the selection is removed at this point, when the finger is lifted? Isn't this still undesired?

And yes, you're still correct, I think last time when I test my patch, I forgot to drop the vendorred vte which I applied my first patch before.

I'm truly sorry about all of that, wasted your time. I think we can forget my patch now. Do you have another idea ?

events.target_title: Keywords vs Labels
Keywords vs Labels

note.body:
I think the reason I'm leaning towards keywords is that the labels interface is not that great when you have a lot of labels. At the rate I'm going, I can see eventually having hundreds of labels. 

*  Currently, it shows the labels in linear order, which would require a lot of scrolling. 
* Autocomplete when adding labels would be nice. 
* When I add a new document, I almost always have to remove some labels the Bayesian filter applies. If I simultaneously need to add a new label, it doesn't remember the ones I deleted - so I have to do it in two steps: First add the new label, then delete the ones I don't need.
* Adding a label is not quick, and I have to do it often enough. I have to go to a new dialogue and pick a color. I can see the utility of having different colors, but an option that will default to "pick random color" would work quite well.

I'm assuming I make use of a lot more labels than you do? To give you an idea, if I get a bank statement this month, I'll give it 3 labels: BankOfAmerica, 2018, December. 

Perhaps with a better interface I'd stick to labels. For now, it makes sense that I just do BankOfAmerica and put "2018" and "December" as keywords.

Likewise for medical documents I might have a label "Medical" and another label "appendicitis". If I did that for each time I visited my doctor, my list of labels will have a lot of "conditions" (flu, etc). And yet only a few documents (and in many cases, only one) will have a given condition.

I mostly use labels for querying. Perhaps it was meant more for organizing rather than querying?

(Sorry, not meaning to dump on your program. I looked at many alternatives about a year ago and did not find any that is better).

events.target_title: Keywords vs Labels

note.body:
OK, quick question. Can I search via keywords (as in limit to keywords)?

I'll have to go your route because too many labels is Hell. At the same time, to an extent, I don't want my search to be polluted by other documents. 

Let's take taxes as an example. Let's assume that the 2015 tax form refers to 2014 somewhere. So if I do a search using "label:tax 2014", I don't want it to return the 2015 form in the results. Having a label for 2014 is weighty. But adding a keyword is less so. So something like "label:tax key:2014"

Another issue I'm facing. I have a bunch of ISO standard documents. A typical ISO standard has, say, 7 parts (7 different PDF files). Each one clearly says "Part 1", "Part 2", etc. The problem is each one has a list of all the parts. So simply searching `label:iso "part 4"` will give me all the parts. If I add the part to the keyword and can restrict to keyword searches, it would help a lot.

As for medical documents, I have a document for each doctor's visit (my doctor's office emails them to me). So over, say, 10 years, I'll have quite a few documents. So it would be useful to pull all the documents related to a certain condition.

events.target_title: Keywords vs Labels

note.body:
I think the dialog may suffice. Let me try it for a few months to see if it is a pain point or not.

As for the ISO document, let's ignore the weirdness of the ISO committee not releasing it as one PDF, but consider any case where you might have Volume 1, Volume 2, etc. Now within these documents, you'll find statements like (consult entry X in Volume Y). Then if you want to get the Volume 5 PDF, finding it without keywords would be impossible - a search for "Volume 5" would return multiple volumes. And for whatever reason, on my system, Paperwork is a bit slow. It will give me N results, and then I have to click each one, wait for it to load - it will usually show the multiple page view, and the pages are too small, so I need to zoom in or switch to single page view - and then I'll know if this is the document I'm looking for. It takes several seconds for each document.

(This issue is on my Windows machine - will have to check if it exists on my Linux machine as well).

>  Next year I'm going to do a full rewrite/reorganization of the code. Since I'm having a problem somehow related with that with my phone bills, I think I will make it possible to have many PDFs inside a same document. That should solve this issue.

I honestly could not follow you here. 

>Correct me if I'm wrong, but assuming OCR did work fine on those documents, you can simply search the name of conditions and get all the documents related to it, no ? Or is the condition not specified on those documents (just the drugs or something) ?

In general this may be true. I'm thinking of a particular problem my pet had, and it involved multiple visits to the vet, with a lot of paperwork, including billing statements, etc. I doubt all of them list the name of the condition. Additionally, medical conditions can have long, complex names, that I may have trouble remembering the spelling. It's easier for me to remember "eyeinfection" than "keratitis".

Don't read too much into what I'm saying. Let me try the dialog approach for keywords and see if it suffices. Everything I mentioned is a real issue I've faced - not a hypothetical. But they are not all yet acute problems.

events.target_title: Feature Request: Have a way to open PDFs in an external reader
Keywords vs Labels

note.body:
Actually, I don't mind the search time (or perhaps I don't have enough documents for it to be slow). I meant the interface when looking at a document (going to the next page, zooming in/out, etc). It's not *terrible*, but it is noticeable. 

As an example, I just clicked on a document that was 86 pages. It took about 3 seconds before it *started* showing that document's pages. Add another second or two to have it show me the first page (after double clicking it). If I do a search and get 10 documents, and have to do this with each one to find the one I want, that's painful. 

More related to my other issue I have open: In a regular PDF reader, I'm used to hitting page down until the portion of the document becomes visible. With paperwork, repeatedly pressing Page down just shows me the animation. So I have to press PgDn, wait for the page to show up (about 0.3-0.5s), and then press again. 

>The idea here would be to make it possible to have a single Paperwork document containing multiple PDF files. They would simply be displayed one after the other, as a single document.
(however this will require further thought regarding reordering of the pages / PDF)

Please don't do that based on my ISO example. Most people will likely want to keep them as separate files. In my example, out of the 10 parts, I consult 2 of them very often, another 2 once in a while, and the rest very occasionally. It's convenient to have them in separate PDFs so I can jump straight to the part I want.

note.body:
Hello,

thank you for the kind responses.

The times for `bzip2` above are about what Gimp takes to save the image as foo.xcf.bz2. It's easy to replicate this yourself if you don't find it meaningful.

I would like to use lbzip2 to speed this up, and take up less space. My use case is photo editing, and saving and loading these images is a nice opportunity to chat or rest my hands. But I start to get a bit scared of crashes and find myself not saving as much.

I am a first time contributor to the Gimp, and know nothing about the code base, or where plugins are. I'm not asking other people to do this for me, but it would be helpful if someone can give me a tips on where to look to get this done (thanks Michael!).

It would be nice if I can do this so that I can contribute it to be used by the project rather than just use it myself. So I ask for your guidance on how I could do this in a way acceptable to the project. This weekend I will do some more editing, so will do the code then.

It seems here is the file-compressor plugin:
    https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/master/plug-ins/common/file-compressor.c#L749

Here's some python-ish code of how I propose to change it.
```
lbzip2_path = shutil.which('lbzip2')
if lbzip2_path is not None:
    infile | lbzip2 -9 > outfile
else:
    previous_bzip_save_code(infile, outfile)
```

I found https://www.gimp.org/develop/ and HACKING but is there any other developer guide?
I couldn't find how to add test cases, or how to update documentation?


best regards,

events.target_title: evince cannot open pdf with AESV3 256 encryption

note.body:
I'm still seeing this problem with evince 3.30.2 running on Ubuntu (disco).

1.  **Show some info on qpdf and evince versions.**

        $ dpkg-query --show evince
        evince	3.30.2-1

        $ evince --version
        GNOME Document Viewer 3.30.2

        $ qpdf --version
        qpdf version 8.2.1

2. **Download a PDF to work with.**

        $ wget https://www.adobe.com/support/products/enterprise/knowledgecenter/media/c4611_sample_explain.pdf -q -O plain.pdf
        $ md5sum plain.pdf 
        88bb00da1e9bab21e9cb13248b8770b1  plain.pdf


3. **Encrypt it using qpdf and AES 256.**

        $ rm -f encrypted-256.pdf encrypted-128.pdf
        $ qpdf --encrypt user-secret owner-secret 256 -- plain.pdf encrypted-256.pdf

        $ egrep -a AES encrypted-256.pdf
        << /CF << /StdCF << /AuthEvent /DocOpen /CFM /AESV3 /Length 32 >> >> /Filter /Standard /Length 256 /O <a868eeb995f6ff82543b1f38ab35f99cd9fd3611ddcfbb93f845b895fe64633fbf4e2714dd4dae142ccb602a50ede355> /OE <95e714077d596a65fecf766c94144c09341c9ddedc6f4237852960de7fc6d417> /P -4 /Perms <f708e990e02ae1ddc85b5a120731edc1> /R 6 /StmF /StdCF /StrF /StdCF /U <f972aa5c9877fd6d6650ca7b2705e12141f9d9d711a3378cd5e51c77c5dbc291e5270b54a36015d38b111c1c562a0749> /UE <435b9bd03432ad84261eb3bf19e00ce236e3acc26d831359fa8d2bacf758d1d0> /V 5 >>


        $ qpdf --password=user-secret --show-encryption encrypted-256.pdf
        R = 6
        P = -4
        User password = user-secret
        extract for accessibility: allowed
        extract for any purpose: allowed
        print low resolution: allowed
        print high resolution: allowed
        modify document assembly: allowed
        modify forms: allowed
        modify annotations: allowed
        modify other: allowed
        modify anything: allowed
        stream encryption method: AESv3
        string encryption method: AESv3
        file encryption method: AESv3

4. **Attempt to view with evince.** supplying either user or owner password does not work.


5. **For comparision, try with AES 128 bit.**.  evince works fine here.

        $ qpdf --encrypt user-secret owner-secret 128 --use-aes=y -- plain.pdf encrypted-128.pdf

        $ qpdf --password=owner-secret --show-encryption encrypted-128.pdf
        R = 4
        P = -4
        User password = user-secret
        extract for accessibility: allowed
        extract for any purpose: allowed
        print low resolution: allowed
        print high resolution: allowed
        modify document assembly: allowed
        modify forms: allowed

events.target_title: Use standard menu items in primary menu

note.body:
Well I don't suppose anyone will listen, but I am going to say it anyway, but having upgraded my OS I now get gedit 3.18.3 and it looks absolutely ridiculous with the huge kiddy buttons on the top bar. 

Totally out of place, way over size, and makes it look like a Fisher Price toy.

And now you are going to get rid of the menu bar altogether? And from the looks of it you provide no underlining for keywords to indicate shortcuts? You are breaking years of design that users are accustomed to, for what exactly?

A shame that you have completely destroyed a perfectly excellent little app.

There are a number of us here all saying exactly the same thing. We are all voting with our feet and will no longer be using it (and convinced everyone to keep clear of Gnome altogether). A crying shame as it has been my favourite editor for donkeys years.

Sorry Gnome team, but your UI is absolutely awful. It might be good for 3 year olds, or tablets, or some gaming stuff, but not for grown ups.

I accept that it may be doing stuff that takes a long time.

Other people have to fix that.

I have no plans to add FSAA support to Raqote as it require a somewhat different architecture. events.target_title: Panel as builtin display
elogind support

note.body:
If you add hard dependencies on systemd-only features to everything, then you limit your software to strict systemd-only systems, completely annihilating the idea of "having choice" in *nix systems.

Currently the systemd dependency is optional as far as it is only concerning sysprofd. The dependency can be fulfilled by elogind, too. This small patch extends choice, and is quite harmless. A system with libelogind will not be powered by systemd anyway. All it does is, that the daemon can run on systems that are not powered by systemd. (*)

If a future feature needs a system explicitly powered by systemd, then you can either make that feature optional, or you can begin requiring the user system to be powered by systemd only for the whole of sysprof. The latter case might reduce your user base by all persons who do not wish to go systemd-only.

But at the end of the day, the choice is yours, of course.

Just my 2 cents. Strongly biased, of course. :wink: 

(*) If something does not work as expected, people tend to open bugs with their distribution first, then with elogind, and someone somewhere in between might come and propose a patch to you. At least that's my experience with two years of elogind integration work...

_Edith wanted to mention_: Well, if such future features requiring a systemd powered system will only concern sysprofd, too, then accepting this merge will indeed only lead to a short lived era. Unless those future features can be made optional, without making this hilariously complicated to develop/maintain. :innocent:

events.target_title: elogind support

note.body:
Well, I understand that. I just have looked up what you do _now_ in sysprof, and all you do is using sd-bus (also provided by elogind) to talk via dbus using polkit privilege checking.That's why it looked like a no-brainer for us to support libelogind, too.

I can understand that you do not want to add something that you can't even test. No matter what we say. And the following is not meant to convince you. There just might be more in elogind than you think, and I'd like to add some information, that's all.

> My personal goal as the author and maintainer of much of the current Sysprof implementation is to get the application in a position that we can distribute via Flatpak. The reason I brought Sysprof back from the grave was to integrate it into Builder, which is primarily distributed to developers via Flatpak.

[Void Linux offers a fully functional Gnome-Shell Wayland & flatpak, both without systemd, utilizing elogind instead](https://www.reddit.com/r/linux/comments/66ass2/update_void_linux_offers_a_fully_functional/), for a year now.

> Supporting that meant improving how we got access to syscall()s that require root capabilities without exposing the application to root. This also allowed us to support Wayland, where most of our users are.

Plasma and Gnome work just fine on Wayland using elogind for over a year now. Non-root non-suid xorg-server is in the works.

> Currently, that escalation is performed by the sysprofd helper. Without it, hardly anything works as all the `perf()` syscalls will likely fail, making Sysprof useless.

The helper just uses dbus and polkit to ask for permission. Actually this has nothing to do with systemd. I think an important piece of information is, that the whole `sd-bus` thing is only a convenience wrapper to make it easier to talk via dbus with other applications/services. With some perks, of course.

But I do not really know what you mean with `perf() syscalls`. Are you talking about functionality like  the [Userland tools for Linux Performance Counters](https://perf.wiki.kernel.org/) provide?

> Portable services may be one way we can approach that in a safe, consistent, and user-authorized manner.

I do not exactly know what that means, but [elogind works fine in docker apps](https://github.com/elogind/elogind/issues/52#issuecomment-381320125), if that is relevant.

Well, I do not really see anything that specifically needs systemd. But then, I have no wider knowledge of the whole eco-system you talk about, so maybe it is best to simply trust your judgement.

In the meantime, we could test what you could not, if that is of any help.

events.target_title: Problem with thumbnailer hardening and debian alternative mechanism
Gimp should install itself as a thumbnailer service for XCF files

note.body:
About this subject, please let me add a comment defending the availability of an external binary to generate the thumbnails.

I normally intercept the thumbnail generation to add a little icon on the image, to rapidly distinguish the GIMP files from exported formats. This is not working anymore due to the fact that GIMP creates its own thumbnail. This is a pity enough, but the worst thing is that something (another program, a backup manager, a simple `cp` from the command line) adds a `.xcf` file, now we have: 

![image](/uploads/e85112a4f3e1e866cb0a5f15348f6413/image.png)

...which I find is a regression. I am trying to find a way to use `gimp-console` to generate the thumbnails as a stop gap for the last case, but I can't think how to fix the first one.

events.target_title: Gimp should install itself as a thumbnailer service for XCF files

note.body:
> We don't need anyone defending anything. I think everybody agree that a thumbnailer executable would be neat. All it takes is someone implementing it. Patches welcome.

Sorry --- you're right. Unfortunately, my programming skills are not at the needed level for something like GIMP. But will try on a script...

> It's neat, how does it work?

I use this script, installed in `/usr/bin/xcf-thumb`: 
```bash
#!/bin/bash

tmpfile1=$(tempfile --prefix xcft --suffix .png)

# remove the file if something strange happens
trap 'rm -rf $tmpfile1' INT EXIT TERM

die() {
  echo >&2 "$@"
  rm -rf $tmpfile1
  exit 1
}
 
# The script will be called with parameters : -s %s %u %o
# -s %s: vertical size,  %u: input url, %o: output file

if [ $1 = "-s" ]; then 
   size=$2
   uin=$3
   fout=$4
else
   size=32 #default size
   uin=$1
   fout=$2
fi

# uin es una url, eliminar "file://"
fin="${uin#file://*}"

gnome-xcf-thumbnailer -s $size "$fin" $tmpfile1 || die "gnome-xcf-thumbnailer failed"
composite -gravity southeast  \
   \(  -resize $((size/2))x$((size/2)) /usr/share/gimp/2.0/images/wilber.png \) \
   \( -resize $sizex$size $tmpfile1 \)  "$fout" || die "convert failed"
rm -rf $tmpfile1
exit 0
```

and then just substitute this script in the `/usr/share/thumbnailers/xcf.thumbnailer` file:
```
[Thumbnailer Entry]
Exec=/usr/bin/xcf-thumb -s %s %i %o
MimeType=image/x-xcf;image/x-compressed-xcf;
```
and it all work(ed). 

Notice there is a problem if your distro uses `bwrap` described [here](http://www.bernaerts-nicolas.fr/linux/74-ubuntu/360-ubuntu-nautilus-external-thumbnailer-failure), [here](https://askubuntu.com/questions/1088539/custom-thumbnailers-don-t-work-on-ubuntu-18-10-and-18-04) and [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-desktop/issues/92). 

> I am pretty sure that GIMP was already creating thumbnails in 2.8. Are you saying it was not?

I am not sure, in truth. But with the stock Ubuntu 18.04 GIMP (2.8.22) my script was called, now it seems that it is bypassed.

events.target_title: Gimp should install itself as a thumbnailer service for XCF files

note.body:
For what I know by experience, basically the thumbnailers are command-line executable:

``` 
thumbnailer -s size inurl outf
```
`size` is an integer, normally 32, 64, 128, 256: it's the biggest pixel size of the resulting image. If not provided, it is 32. 

`inurl` is a `gvfs` specification (`file:///absolute/path/file.xcf` is the normal one) 

`outf` is the output file, normally comes with  `.png` extension, for the thumbnail image.

events.target_title: Gimp should install itself as a thumbnailer service for XCF files

note.body:
But please notice that I do not think there is a standard API; the script is called by the desktop system and how to call ir is described in the `/usr/share/thumbnailers/*.thumbnailer` files, so anything able to export a PNG with a given size is OK. I am using `dcraw` to generate raw photo files thumbnails with no problem at all.

Also, I think that gimp should not write directly the thumbnails (or at least it should be configurable), because it bypasses the desktop layer and make it impossible to reconfigure/personalize them.

events.target_title: g_function_info_invoke() may truncate return values
g_function_info_invoke() may truncate return values

note.body:
Ok. If I understand you correctly, a GI-supported pointer return type must fall into one of the following categories:

1. a pointer to an integral type. This must be annotated as an array (or utf8).
2. a pointer to a 'complex' type (e.g. Gobject/struct etc).
3. a pointer to an opaque type. The return type must be void*.

GI handles the above three cases well. Obviously gdk_pixbuf_read_pixels() doesn't fall into any of the above categories; without a length arg the closest it comes to is category 3.

events.target_title: tests: shm: fix pwrite wrapper with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

note.body: Yes, normally glibc will handle this correctly, but this test includes a wrapper which uses `dlsym()` to directly call the `pwrite` symbol, bypassing the logic in the glibc headers which selects the correct implementation. This means the wrapper needs to implement the selection logic itself.

events.target_title: tests: shm: fix pwrite wrapper with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

note.body: That seems like a much more robust solution.

events.target_title: tests: shm: fix pwrite wrapper with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

note.body:
I've started looking through the code, and this solution seems more complicated than I thought. There is a `libdconf_mock` library, which is linked to some of the tests, but not to the `shm` test. This is because `libdconf_mock` mocks the shm library, while the `shm` test should obviously be testing the real implementation. There doesn't seem to be a good way to mock/wrap a single function without using a similar hack with `dlsym()`.

A possible solution is to introduce a `dconf_shm_pwrite` function, but wrap it using `dlsym`, which would be more robust than directly wrapping `pwrite` because there will be no renaming trickery going on behind the scenes.

events.target_title: tests: shm: fix pwrite wrapper with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

note.body:
I'll try it, but I don't know if it will work because you would have to link to both the mock library, which would contain just `dconf_shm_pwrite`, and the real dconf shm library (which also defines `dconf_shm_pwrite`), and I don't know if the correct symbol would be chosen or if this would cause linker errors.

Otherwise you would have to add wrappers for all the shm functions in the mock library, and you would be back to using `dlsym`.

events.target_title: tests: shm: fix pwrite wrapper with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

note.body: After experimenting with this, I realized that this approach won't work with the current test setup. The dconf libraries are statically linked into the test binary, so there is no easy way to wrap/override a symbol in them. The current pwrite `dlsym` trick works because the `pwrite` symbol is in a dynamically linked library.

events.target_title: Text rendering: Support subpixel glyph placement

note.body:
What needs to happen for this to go ahead?

Lack of subpixel positioning results in some pretty bad kerning issues with ClearType functionality enabled in FreeType. Namely, native byte code interpreter (full hinting) and subpixel rendering result in non-integer advance widths which destroys kerning if glyphs cannot be positioned with sub-pixel precision. Remaining patents for ClearType expire in July, so we can expect that this will become a more common use case once subpixel rendering becomes the default.

Screenshots with examples are available in FreeType's bugtracker: https://savannah.nongnu.org/bugs/?54555

Chromium also ran into this, but Skia already supports subpixel positioning so there it was an easy fix: https://crbug.com/740385 https://crbug.com/824153

In case of virtually everything else on desktop Linux including GTK, Cairo is the library used for font rendering and it does not currently support subpixel positioning. I guess it needs to be added there first. I managed to find this piece by Behdad Esfahbod of Cairo and David Turner of FreeType from 2008 on the topic: https://lists.cairographics.org/archives/cairo/2008-May/014160.html

Seems like a non-trivial issue, but I don't know how accurate it still is 11 years later.

events.target_title: Text rendering: Support subpixel glyph placement

note.body: Cairo mailing lists look pretty dead. Given that they recently released 1.17.2 there must be something that team uses to communicate, so I will give IRC a shot. The patch got Behdad's blessing originally, I take that as a good sign.

events.target_title: Symlinked Trashing works but Trash display doesn't
Symlinked Trashing works but Trash display doesn't

note.body:
I am not sure how to find out my glib version but I have installed those packages:

```
glibc.x86_64 2.28-26.fc29
cglib.noarch 3.2.4-8.fc29
```

So vanilla Fedora 29. My `fstab`

```
UID=4213a9c9-b67a-4d1f-a0ec-xxxxxxxxxxx /                       ext4    defaults        1 1
UUID=3e36d3c8-34b1-4cbd-b3b9-xxxxxxxxxxx /boot                   ext4    defaults        1 2
UUID=1244-xxxx          /boot/efi               vfat    umask=0077,shortname=winnt 0 2
UUID=670416f5-2f9f-4fdd-b19a-xxxxxxxxxxx /home                   ext4    defaults        1 2
UUID=88bf2d10-3d8d-459a-969e-xxxxxxxxxxx /home/maweki/.local     ext4    defaults        1 2
UUID=5384a9c8-bb6a-4c49-8e5f-xxxxxxxxxxx swap                    swap    defaults        0 0
```

`~/.local` is owned by me with the appropriate access.

> I wonder if there is any reason to mount `.local` on a different drive?

I have it on an SSD. So my day-to-day-files (pictures, music, etc.) is on a spinning disk. `/` and `swap` are on an m2-ssd. And my local environment for locally built packages, shell-extensions, etc. (everything "running" locally) is on an ssd. It's not a bad idea, I'd  say.

events.target_title: Symlinked Trashing works but Trash display doesn't

note.body:
> It seems that XDG spec doesn't enforce `XDG_DATA_HOME` to be on the same mount as `HOME`, but I would say that trash spec silently expects this.

As I've read it, the trash directory should be on the same partition and that is true since I've symlinked `XDG_DATA_HOME/Trash` to something in my home directory. And trashing works fine and as expected. Only listing the trash does not work correctly for the symlinked trash dir.

events.target_title: No useful zoom level for larger documents possible (no zoom farther than 20%)

note.body:
This is still an issue in 3.30.2. You can't zoom out more than to 20% which is useless for larger documents.

I've created a 200in wide pdf (attached). [Zeichnung.pdf](/uploads/30ab478de79b71ef87e01e07f5e8e5d6/Zeichnung.pdf)

You can fit to width (which doesn't work for electronic graphic novels because some pages are in a different format and so it fits to the largest page) but if you use normal zoom, you can't zoom out to more than 20%. You should at least be able to zoom as far as the fit-to-width-option (which works).

Or at least be able to enter a different zoom level but it always resets to 20%.

events.target_title: No useful zoom level for larger documents possible (no zoom farther than 20%)

note.body:
This is not a duplicate!

The zoom does work (try fit-to-width) and the zoom factor works quite well. You just can't enter the correct factor.

Here is the proof:
![Bildschirmfoto_von_2019-02-02_13-11-55](/uploads/d21ca2e2e811c433b83927517a8228fe/Bildschirmfoto_von_2019-02-02_13-11-55.png)

Fit-to-width sets the zoom level to a working(!!!) 4.8%. But if I try to enter 7% it flips back to 20%. This is a UI issue.

Edit:
Also the other issue is about zooming into a pdf. This is a large pdf that is zoomed out, not a small one zoomed in.

events.target_title: GIMP cannot open DNG format files as it cannot find installed RawTherapee 5.4

note.body:
The issue is not limited to DNG files but generally to raw files.
I verified  that, when installing Rawtherapee5.5, the HKLM or HKCU keys are created and filled.
I tried also the 2 methods:setting  PATH variable, setting RAWTHERAPEE_EXECUTABLE.

As the Darktable plugin is working, I suppose there is either
- a bug somewhere in `file-rawtherapee.c` 
- or a bug in the way rawtherapee.exe itself answers to file-rawtherapee to register it. 
- or in the way rawtherapee. exe or rawtherapee-cli.exe are called when processing a raw file

I cannot go further as there is no debug output in File-rawtherapee.c and I did not succeed to build GIMP2.10.8 raw plugins on W10/MSYS2. I am not able or willing to build on another system.
edit : I built GIMP2.10.8

events.target_title: GIMP cannot open DNG format files as it cannot find installed RawTherapee 5.4

note.body:
After building GIMP, I launched it from a MNGW64 shell.
To my great surprise, Rawtherapee is found and started when opening a raw.

So I came back to the gimp.org 2.10.8 build

When GIMP.exe is directly launched by double-clicking or by a shortcut, RT opens a window at init and indeed is not registered as a plugin.

If I launch the same exe through a MINW64 shell, Rawtherapee is found and started ok!

Odd popover positioning in playlist view on small window size

note.body:
The problem seems to be this: the rectangle the popover points to is too tall. When there isn't enough space to show the popover at the bottom or at the top, (which is the case when the window is small), the popover chooses to show up on the side. Changing the rectangle's height to the height of a row in the treeview fixes the bug.

If this is still a problem I can submit a pull request. ![Screenshot_from_2018-12-24_16-07-50](/uploads/e3f037589b05209491747f2cd528e4a2/Screenshot_from_2018-12-24_16-07-50.png)

note.body:
I agree that `get_visible_rect()` is not useful at all. However, the height of the rectangle is used to give the popover some distance from the mouse, which looks nice in my opinion. I would suggest the following:

    rect = Gdk.Rectangle()   
    rect.height = self._view.get_cell_area(path, None).height  
    rect.x = x  
    rect.y = y - rect.height / 2.0

events.target_title: Security popover for some sites switches from strong to none after reload
Security popover for some sites switches from strong to none after reload

note.body:
I have some more information that might help identify the issue. I found that I can consistently cause the warning icon to appear if an affected website is restored upon startup. Also, I can then make the issue disappear by manually typing in *just* the domain name into the location bar and pressing Enter. (Typing in just the domain name is important, because if I try navigating to the same web page as opposed to just the domain name, then the issue does not disappear. So perhaps HTTP redirects have something to do with this?) 

Here's a video demonstrating this on todoist.com. In the video, I start by navigating to "todoist.com", and I see the strong-security icon. Then, I close Epiphany and re-open it. Upon re-opening, the previous web page is restored, but now the icon is the no-security icon. I then navigate to "todoist.com", and although I get redirected back to the same web page, the icon is now the strong-security icon.

![Epiphany_Security_Level_Bug_-_2](/uploads/dd7ba407f89cfbcf7725d523f6d880a7/Epiphany_Security_Level_Bug_-_2.webm)

Thanks for your help in investigating this. I appreciate it, and let me know if I can provide some more information.

events.target_title: Security popover for some sites switches from strong to none after reload

note.body: I wasn't able to find a way to reproduce this if I wasn't logged in on todoist.com, unfortunately. I'll try to find some other sites that exhibit the issue. I'll also try to install the Flatpak version.

events.target_title: Security popover for some sites switches from strong to none after reload

note.body:
I'm still trying to find another website that easily reproduces this issue. So far, I have only been able to reproduce this on todoist.com, and only after logging in. I thought I could reproduce it on https://ca.yahoo.com/?p=us before, but it doesn't seem to be happening there anymore. 

I also tried this using Epiphany Technology Preview, I was indeed able to reproduce the issue. I installed the Epiphany Technology Preview using the following command:
```
~$ flatpak install --from https://webkitgtk.org/epiphany-tech-preview
```

I'll keep trying to find other websites that exhibit this behavior, but maybe at this point, I should try attaching a debugger and debugging this? I haven't worked on Epiphany before, so I might need some help. My thinking was that if I set a breakpoint in lib/widgets/ephy-security-popover.c and see what's changing the `EphySecurityLevel` from `EPHY_SECURITY_LEVEL_STRONG_SECURITY` to `EPHY_SECURITY_LEVEL_NO_SECURITY`, maybe that would help identify what's causing this.

events.target_title: Security popover for some sites switches from strong to none after reload

note.body:
I decided to try debugging this. I figured even if I can't find the problem, I'd probably learn a thing or two along the way :). By setting breakpoints in `update_security_status_for_committed_load`, I found that `webkit_web_view_get_tls_info` is returning false when the bug occurs. (It returns true when there's no bug.) This then results in calling `ephy_web_view_set_security_level` with `security_level` set to `EPHY_SECURITY_LEVEL_NO_SECURITY`.

I've been doing this using GNOME Builder and the "Easy Way", as described on the Epiphany [Contribute](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Web/Development) page, so I wasn't able to step into the WebKit code to see what was going on. Any ideas about what to check next? 

Perhaps next weekend I'll try to get JHBuild set up and try to debug into WebKit code itself.

note.body:
Thank you for doing all that research! I tried using JHBuild to build Epiphany along with WebKitGTK and libsoup, but after multiple attempts, I couldn't get it to work. I eventually got it all compiled, but when I ran Epiphany, the web process would immediately crash. In the terminal, I would get this error:

```
free(): invalid pointer

** (epiphany:20092): WARNING **: 20:24:45.321: Web process crashed
```

So instead, I decided to try using BuildStream using the instructions at [Newcomers/BuildSystemComponent](https://wiki.gnome.org/Newcomers/BuildSystemComponent). This seemed to work much more reliably, but I've run into another issue, for which I filed a bug: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-build-meta/issues/123.

Once I've gotten through building Epiphany with WebKitGTK and libsoup, I'll use the information you provided to debug further!

events.target_title: Launching Too Many Terminals

note.body:
This also happens to me (Fedora 31, gnome-3.34 running Xorg)

I have Ctrl+Alt+T as a custom shortcut defined in the "Keyboard Shortcuts" section of Settings with the command "gnome-terminal"

events.target_title: [calendar panel on  v.3.34.1+] : "All day event" are duplicated...

note.body:
I can also reproduce this and some additional strangeness, such as:
* Appointments showing at the completely wrong time
* Appointments not being updated when their time changes

Attached are two screen shots, one showing gnome calendar and the other showing gnome-shell. There are three things to notice here:
1. Just like the title of this ticket, there is an all day event (Béla Fleck) on Friday the 22nd which shows correctly in gnome-calendar, but shows up on the 21st in gnome-shell
1. In gnome-calendar, there is an event at 09:00AM (Green box starting with A). However, in gnome-shell, this is showing as 03:00AM!
1. In gnome-calendar, there is an event at 14:30 (Green box). This meeting was originally scheduled for 08:30, but was later changed by a remote invitation. gnome-calendar correctly updated to 14:30, but gnome-shell still shows it at the old time of 08:30

I would also like to point out that evolution's calendar correctly shows all the appointments.

This is on fedora 31 running gnome-shell-3.34.1-4.fc31.x86_64 under Xorg.![Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_12-10-40](/uploads/d60d3c88be70eaa5820f812d473700aa/Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_12-10-40.png)

![Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_12-10-10](/uploads/3f4a78ca89d44f272a250daf833bb522/Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_12-10-10.png)
